categories.title: Tips & Need to know
categories.description: Singapore has an impressive global dining scene. Today, there's everything on offer from Brazillian steaks to modern British cuisine.

items.title: Health & Emergencies
items.description: Dial 999 for police and 995 for fire or ambulance\nCall 1777 if you need an ambulance in non-emergency situations.

items.title: Money
items.description: The Singapore dollca (S$/SGD)is the official currentcy of Singapore. Coins come in denominatinos of 5/10/20/50 cents and S$1.

categories.title: Food & Drink
categories.description: Singapore has an impressive global dining scene. Today, there's everything on offer from Brazillian steaks to modern British cuisine.

items.title: Song Fa Bak Kut Teh
items.description: Crowds line up at this cozy eatery known for its bak kut teh (pork ribs in broth) & braised meats.

items.title: Bar Bar Black Sheep
items.description: Offer wide range of food (Indian, Thai & Western) with very affordable price.

categories.title: Favorite Spots
categories.description: Singapore has an impressive global dining scene. Today, there's everything on offer from Brazillian steaks to modern British cuisine.

items.title: Universal Studios Singapore
items.description: Movie amusement park with sets & rides on themes from Hollywood to sci-fi, plus live entertainment.

items.title: Gardens by the Bay
items.description: A network of modern green houses & waterfront parks containing super trees lined with solar cells.

categories.title: Getting around
categories.description: Singapore has an impressive global dining scene. Today, there's everything on offer from Brazillian steaks to modern British cuisine.

items.title: On Arrival
items.description: The quickest way to the city center from Changi Airport (SIN) about 18 kilometers, is by taxi. A more economical option is to take the subway train, known as the MRT (mass rapid transport), which has numerous stations throughout the city.

items.title: Taxi service
items.description: Taxis are relatively cheap and widely available, but harder to find during rush hour or when it's raining. Fares follow a strict meter system and taxi drivers can't charge extra. Basic fare starts at S$3-S$3.9, with increments of S$0.22 per 400 meters.\nDuring business hours in the city center, taxis are not allowed to pick up passengers on the street.
